name: Paraguayan War (War of the Triple Alliance)
description: The devastating 1864-1870 war in which Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay fought Paraguay. Paraguay lost 60-90% of its population, including most adult males. The victors imposed harsh terms and territorial losses. One of the deadliest conflicts in modern history by proportion of population killed.

mortality.note: Paraguay lost 60-90% of its population - possibly highest proportion in any modern war. Pre-war population estimates vary (400,000-1,300,000), making percentages uncertain. Up to 90% of adult males killed. Deaths from combat, disease, and starvation. War continued even after outcome was certain, devastating civilian population.

rationales.systematic_intensity: War of annihilation. Brazil and Argentina continued fighting after Paraguay was effectively defeated. Civilian massacres documented. But no industrial extermination infrastructure.
rationales.profit: British loans financed Triple Alliance. Paraguay's independent economy (state-owned industries, no foreign debt) threatened regional trade patterns. Post-war Paraguay opened to foreign capital.
rationales.ideology: Framed as 'civilizing' war against López's 'barbarism'. National honor narratives on all sides. Paraguay's resistance became suicidal national mission.
rationales.complicity: British banking interests benefited. Argentine and Brazilian elites gained territory. International community ignored devastation.

analysis.pattern_note: Possibly the deadliest war in modern history by population percentage. Paraguay - a small nation with state-controlled economy and no foreign debt - was destroyed by its larger neighbors, financed by British banks. Francisco Solano López refused surrender even as his nation was annihilated. Post-war Paraguay lost 60% of territory and became dependent on foreign capital. A forgotten war: most people outside South America have never heard of it, despite death toll rivaling major 20th century conflicts. Shows how 'small' wars can be proportionally more devastating than world wars.
warning_signs: Small nation surrounded by larger powers
analysis.root_causes: Territorial disputes, Paraguayan economic independence threatening British trade interests, regional power struggles, López's miscalculated aggression
